       At this stage, ld. Counsel for accused persons seeks time to deposit 
the   compensation   amount.   Heard.   Time   granted.   Put   on  17.10.2012  for

       ld.   APP   argued   on   sentence   and   submits   that   already    accused 

Surender Rai is acquitted for the offences punishable u/s   376 / 366   IPC 

and   accused  Yogita  and  Manoj   Kumar  are   also   acquitted   against   the 

offences   u/s   376/   506   IPC.       Ld.   APP   further   submits   that   accused 

Surender Rai has been convicted for the offence u/s 
                                                   506­II  read with 354
                                                                         




                                                                                     3 
 IPC and  accused persons Yogita  and Manoj Kumar have been convicted 

for the offences punishable u/s 109 r/w 509 IPC.    ld. APP further submits 

that  a   severe   punishment   be  awarded   to  accused   Surender   Rai   ,   since 

unchastity   to   a   woman,   is   punishable   with   imprisonment   of   either 

description for a term which may extend to  seven years, or with fine, or 

with both under section  506 Part II of IPC.   Ld. APP further argued and 

submits that a severe punishment be also awarded to remaining accused 

persons   i.e.   Yogita   and   Manoj   Kumar   who   assisted   main   accused   in 

committing such offence.  

       Contrary   to   the   submissions   of   ld.   APP,   Ld.   counsel  for   the 

accused Surender Rai argued and submits that accused is aged about 29 

years old.   He again submits that  accused is a married person and he has 

one small children   and wife of accused Surender Rai is pregnant.   The 

offence   u/s 376 IPC could not be proved on record hence, accused has 

been acquitted for the offence u/s 376 IPC.    He has old age mother who is 

aged   about   70   years   old.   Elder   brother   of   accused   Surender   Rai   has 

already been expired.    Ld. Counsel again submits that accused Surender 

Rai has ailing parents and they needs the presence of accused with them 

to look after.  He is the only bread earner in his family.    He further submits 

that accused has no previous criminal history and he   has never misused 

the   liberty   of   bail   and   never   tried   to   cause   any   interruption   in   the 

administration of justice.       He has already remained in custody for about 




                                                                                          4 
 one   month.     On   these   grounds   ld.   Counsel   for   the   accused   prayed   for 

release of accused on probation of good conduct.   

       Ld. Counsel for accused Yogita and Manoj Kumar submits that they 

are husband and wife.  They have small children to look after.  The offence 

u/s   376   IPC   could   not   be   proved   on   record   hence,   accused   has   been 

acquitted for the offence u/s 376 IPC.     Ld. Counsel again submits that 

accused persons have ailing parents and small  school going children to 

look after.       He further submits that accused persons have no previous 

criminal history and they have never misused the liberty of bail and never 

tried to cause any interruption in the administration of justice.     On these 

grounds   ld.   Counsel   for   the   accused   prayed   for   release   of   accused   on 

probation of good conduct.

       Keeping   in   view   the   present   scenario   and   the   facts   and 

circumstances   of   the   case   and   that   wife   of   accused   Surender   Rai   is 

pregnant so to my view ends of justice shall be met if accused Surender 

Rai is released on probation of good conduct on furnishing personal bond 

of   Rs.10,000/­   with   one   surety   in   the   like   amount     for  2   years    further 

subject   to   the   condition   that   he   shall   pay  compensation  amount   of 

Rs.30,000/­ to the victim Pooja @ Monika.   Again, ends of justice shall be 

met   if     accused   persons   namely  Yogita  and  Manoj   Kumar  are   also 

released   on   probation   of   good   conduct   on   furnishing   personal   bond   of

 Rs.10,000/­   each   with   one   surety   in   the   like   amount     each   for  2   years 

further subject to the condition that they shall pay compensation amount of

JUDGEMENT

1. Briefly facts of the prosecution case are that in the month of January 2005 accused Surender Rai met Ms. Pooja @ Monika and proposed her for marriage. Thereafter, as per the allegations made by the prosecutrix accused Surender Rai took her to the house of her sister with assurance that his sister and brother­in­law (Manoj Kumar and Yogita) called her for tea and wanted to see her. On this pretext accused Surender Rai had 7 taken the prosecutrix to the house of her sister where her sister and brother­in­law were available who prepared the tea and after serving the tea they came out from room. The room was locked from the out side by them. The offence of rape was committed by the accused Surender in connivance with the co­accused persons since they had instigated accused Surender Rai to commit the sexual intercourse against the wishes of prosecutrix Pooja @ Monika. Accordingly, accused persons were arrested and booked for the offences punishable u/s 376/ 366/ 506 / 34 IPC. I.O. of the case after completion of the usual investigation filed the challan before the court. This case was committed to the Sessions Court and received on 15.12.2008 for trial as it pertains to the heinous crime committed under section 376/ 366/ 506 IPC which is exclusively triable by court of Sessions.

2. Ld. Predecessor of this court after having gone through the material available on record and settled case law, framed a charge for the offences u/s 376/ 366/ 506 IPC against accused Surender Rai and another charge for the offences u/s 109 r/w 376/ 506 IPC against accused Amar Nath and Yogita, vide order dated 28.01.2009.

3. To prove and substantiate its case the prosecution has examined witnesses namely PW1 HC Ajay Pal - formal witness being MHCM at 8 PS Tilak Nagar on 01.11.06. He got exhibited the copy of entry of depositing of case property as Ex.PW1/A and copy of sending the same to FSL as PW1/B; PW2 HC Amit Kumar is a formal as well as material witness. He stated that a DD was registered at PP Raghubir Nagar regarding missing of a woman Pooja Aggarwal along with two children.

Thereafter, on 02.11.06 Surender and Pooja Agarwal came to PP. He testified that Pooja stated that she had gone with accused of her own.

He further deposed that WSI Rajni came to PP Raghbir Nagar and informed that a case has already been registered against accused and then accused was taken by WSI Rajni;

4. PW3 HC Virender is the formal witness being duty officer at PS Tilak Nagar on 01.11.06. He got exhibited the copy of FIR as Ex.PW3/A which was recorded by him on the basis of rukka presented by WSI. He also got exhibited the endorsement as Ex.PW3/B; PW4 Ct. Vinod - he accompanied the I.O. In the investigation on 01.11.06; PW5 Harvinder Pal Singh - Sub­Registrar - Birth and Death, formal witness got exhibited the copy of entry of date of birth of prosecutrix at serial no.776 as Ex.PW5/A and copy of birth certificate as Ex.PW5/B; PW6 Dr. Uday Kumar Singh - CMO DDU Hospital , formal witness he testified on 01.11.06 Pooja @ Monika , 19 years female was examined vide MLC 9 no.28229 which is Ex.PW6/A and she was sent for gyane examination;

PW7 Ct. Harjinder - formal witness ­ he took the pulanda to CFSL office Calcutta, on 27.12.2006. All these witnesses have not been cross­ examined.

5. PW8 Dr. Bhawan Saxena, CMO DDU Hospital is a formal witness he examined the accused on 02.11.06 vide MLC Ex.PW8/A. He opined that there is no evidence to suggest that the patient is unable to perform the act of sex. This witness has been cross­examined. He admitted that he has mentioned in MLC that according to history given by patient underwear has been changed as the medical examination is being conducted 16 days after the incident.

6. PW9 Smt. Monika @ Pooja is the star witness of this case being victim.

For the sake of brevity and convenience let her statement is being re­ produced verbatim which is as under:­ "On 01/11/06 I came to know that accused Surender Rai present in court today has run away. I was in love with the accused Surender Rai and Surender Rai also used to love with me and accused Surender Rai had promised to marry me. Accused Surender Rai had even come to my house to talk to my mother and my mother was willing to get me married to the accused saying that the boy and the family were good and she told him that he should consult his family and we will consult ours. My family was willing to marry me off to the accused but the accused had not informed his family. The accused took me and introduced to his sister and Jijaji and they used to reside in Hari 10 Nagar. The sister and Jijaji also gifted me a Sari and lots of talks were going on in the family and I also used to keep fast of Karva Chauth. The two photographs on record are shown to the witness and the witness identifies the photographs which were taken on Karva Chauth. The accompanying boy in the photograph is accused Surender Rai present in court today. The photographs are Ex Pw9/A nd and Pw9/B. On 22 October 2005 I came to know that accused Surender Rai had run away with some other girl and I had lodged the present complaint on 01/11/06. The complaint is Ex Pw9/C signed by me at point A. I had lodged the complaint since the accused had played a fraud with me saying that he would marry me. The accused had made forcible physical relations with me several times and we had also gone out of station together. All the members of our family came to know about the fact of physical relationship of mine with the accused Surender Rai. Thereafter I came to know that the accused had eloped with one girl then I took all the photographs which was snapped with the accused to his house and shown to his family members for the purpose of convincing them about the relationship. The family members of the accused promised me that I should not made any complaint they also insured me about marrying me with the accused Surender Rai. The parents of the girl Pooja Aggarwal to whom the accused ran away and I had gone to the PS to lodge the complaint. The physical relationship was established by the accused outside the place but I do not know the name of that place. As and when the accused made a physical relationship with me no one from his family was present there however once upon a time we went to the house of sister of the accused where he physically abused me. I cannot identify the sister and his brother in law of the accused since they were faded from my memory as such I could not recollect. At the time of the arrest of the accused Surender Rai I signed on the arrest memo Ex Pw4/A signed by me at point B and the personal search memo Ex Pw4/B signed by me at point B. I also signed the seizure memo of the photographs same is Ex Pw9/D signed by me at point B. I have also signed on the seizure of exhibits Pw9/E signed by me at point A. My date of birth is 23 June 1987 and the photocopy of the certificate of date of birth is Ex Pw5/B and the same was seized by the IO as Ex Pw9/F signed by me at point A. I had also signed on the disclosure of the accused Ex Pw9/G. 11 At this stage Ld.APP request for cross examination of the witness on the role of the co­accused as has not been specifically deposed by the witness. Heard Allowed.

XXXXXXXXBy Ld.APP for State.

I reached the Police Station Tilak Nagar with my mother and Bua, Harpali. At that time one Sh.Devi Sharan Aggarwal was also present there who is Taya/Sasur of Smt.Pooja Aggarwal. It is incorrect to suggest that the SI Rajni hads instigated me to implicate the accused persons in a false case. It is further incorrect to suggest that the present case has been registered on the instigation of the Devi Sharan Aggarwal relative of the Pooja Aggarwal."

7. PW10 Smt. Babli - mother of prosecutrix; PW11 Dr.Namita, S.R. Gyanae, DDU Hospital ­ she examined prosecutrix, she got exhibited 14 the MLC of victim as Ex.PW11/A; PW12 SI Rajni Chopra - I.O. Of the case; PW13 Dr. Aruna Singh - CMO, DDU Hospital - formal witness.

He got exhibited the MLC of prosecutrix as Ex.PW13/A and testified that as per report the patient was not pregnant at the time of ultrasound.

8. Having perused the testimonies of all these witnesses it has come on record that in the year 2005, PW9 Monika @ Puja used to work in a private company in Rajouri Garden, where accused Surender Rai met her and proposed her to marry. Accused Surender Rai took PW9 Monika @ Puja and introduced her to accused Manoj Kumar and Smt.Yogita Accused Manoj Kumar and Smt. Yogita gifted Sari and had talks with her. On one day accused Surender Rai had taken PW9 Monika @ Puja at the residence of co­accused persons where accused Smt. Yogita prepared tea and after having served tea, she along with her husband Manoj went outside the room closing the door from outside. On being closed the door, accused Surender Rai started using force and when PW9 Monika @ Puja refused, accused Surender Rai stated that no harm is going to be caused as he was going to marry with her and when she objected for the same, accused Surender Rai threatened her that he would not marry her and he would get her brother and sister killed and due to which PW9 Monika @ Puja got frightened and when PW9 Monika @ Puja tried to go outside the room, the door of the room was found 15 locked from outside. Accused Surender Rai committed forcible sexual intercourse with Monika @ Puja and at that time co­accused persons Manoj and Yogita were standing outside the room. When PW9 Monika @ Puja started crying, accused Surender Rai asked co­accused persons to open the door and then only co­accused persons opened the door and threatened her not to narrate anything about the incident.

9. Further, on perusal of testimonies of witnesses it has come on record that on 01.11.2006, Puja and her mother Babli came at PS, narrated the incident of rape before PW12 SI Rajni Chopra who recorded statement of Puja vide Ex.PW9/C, made endorsement on the same, vide Ex.PW12/A and accordingly FIR NO.821/06 Ex.PW3/A was recorded by HC Bijender Kumar, the duty officer. Thereafter, PW12 SI Rajni Chopra along with Ct. Vinod, prosecutrix Puja and her mother Babli went to DDU hospital where prosecutrix Puja was medically examined by Dr. Manju vide MLC Ex.PW11/A and Ex.PW6/A. After the medical examination doctor handed over two sealed parcels and one sample seal to the IO and IO has taken the same into her possession vide memo Ex.PW9/B. During the course of investigation, IO had taken the photocopy of date of birth of prosecutrix Puja vide Ex.PW9/F and Ex.PW5/B. On 02.11.2006, accused Surender Rai was arrested. His arrest memo and personal search memo are Ex.PW4/A and B. He was 16 interrogated vide disclosure statement Ex.PW9/J. Accused Surender Rai was taken to DDU Hospital where he was medically examined by PW8 Dr. Bhavan Saxena vide MLC Ex.PW8/A. After the medical examination doctor handed over two sealed parcels and one sample seal which were taken into possession through memo vide Ex.PW4/C. Further, perusal of the testimonies of witnesses it has come on record that during the course of investigation prosecutrix produced two photographs (Ex.PW9/A and B) which were taken into possession vide memo Ex.PW9/D. I.O. also prepared the site plan during the course of investigation which is Ex.PW12/B. Accused Manoj and Yogita were ordered to be released on anticipatory bail and formally arrested. Arrest memo and personal search memo are Ex.PW12/B, C, D and E. On 01.11.2006, PW1 HC Ajay Pal, being MHC(M) made an entry in the store room register regarding deposition of case property at serial no.

5532 and 5533 vide Ex.PW1/A and B and sent four sealed parcels to FSL Kolkata vide RC No.316/21. All these witnesses have also been cross­examined. I have gone through their cross­examination also carefully. I found some minor type of contradictions which are attributable due to the long duration of time and memory of a human being. However, no material contradiction has come on record which may affect the case of the prosecution. On minor type of contradictions 17 the Hon'ble Supreme Court in case State of UP Vs Bhagwan AIR 1997 SC 3292: (1997) 1 SCC 19 made the following observations which are very relevant crucial and dominant in deciding the fate of the present case:­ "minor discrepancies in the evidence of the eye­witnesses are immaterial unless they demolished the basic case of the prosecution".

Observations made in the aforesaid case by the Hon'ble Supreme Court are exfacie indicative of the fact that when contradictions are minor the truthfulness of the witness cannot be discredited in all.

10.After closing prosecution evidence, statements of accused persons u/s 313 Cr. PC were recorded. Accused persons have denied all the allegations and deposed that they have been falsely implicated in this case. In their defence one defence witness namely DW1 Smt.Usha Rani, Oath Commissioner came before the court and she denied to depose regarding the case since she did not produce any document.

11.Arguments were heard at length. It is argued by the ld. Counsel for the accused that prosecutrix is major girl. She was in love with accused Surender Rai. ld. Counsel for accused again submitted that PW9 Pooja has not deposed against co­accused persons namely Manoj Kumar and Yogita. Ld. Counsel for accused again submitted that testimony of 18 PW2 clearly indicates that prosecutrix was consented party since, Pw2 HC Amit Kumar stated that on 02.11.06 Surender and Pooja Agarwal came to PP. He testified that Pooja stated that she had gone with accused of her own. ld. Counsel for accused again submitted that testimony of prosecutrix also indicates that she was consented party.

Ld. Counsel again submitted that there was no injury on the private part of the prosecutrix as per deposition of PW11 Dr. Namita since she has stated that on local examination, her hymen was found intact and no marks of injury were found. On these grounds ld. Counsel for the accused argued and submitted that accused be acquitted since he has not committed any rape.

12.Contrary to it, ld. APP argued and submitted that prosecution has suc­ cessfully proved its case since prosecutrix has correctly identified the ac­ cused as culprit who raped her. Ld. APP further argued and submitted that alone statement of prosecutrix is sufficient to hold the accused guilty in rape cases. In support of his contentions he has stated that it has been held on the point of sexual assault that:

"The testimony of victim in cases of sexual offences is vital and unless there are compelling reasons which necessitate looking for corroboration of her statement, the Courts should find no difficulty to act on the testimony of a victim of sexual assault alone to convict and accused where her testimony inspires confidence and is found to be reliable. Seeking corroboration of her statement before relying upon the same, as a rule, in such cases amounts to adding insult to injury. Why should the evidence of a girl or a woman who complains of rape of sexual molestation, be viewed with doubt, disbelief or suspicion? The court while appreciating 19 the evidence of a prosecutrix may look for some assurance of her statement to satisfy its judicial conscience, since she is a witness who is interested in the outcome of the charge leveled by her, but there is no requirement of law to insist upon corroboration of her statement to base conviction of an accused. The evidence of a victim of sexual assault stands almost at par with the evidence on an injured witness and to an extent is even more reliable. Just as a witness who has sustained some injury in the occurrence, which is not found to be self inflicted, is considered to be a good witness in the sense that he is least likely to shield the real culprit, the evidence of a victim of a sexual offence is entitled to great weight, absence of corroboration notwithstanding. Corroborative evidence is not an imperative component of judicial credence in every case of rape. Corroboration as a condition for judicial reliance on the testimony of the prosecutrix is not a requirement of law but a guidance of prudence under given circumstances. It must not be overlooked that a woman or a girl subjected to sexual assault is not an accomplice to the crime but is a victim of another person's lust and it is improper and undesirable to test her evidence with a certain amount of suspicion, treating her as if she were an accomplice. Inferences have to be drawn from a given set of facts and circumstances with realistic diversity and not dead uniformity lest that type of rigidity I the shape of rule of law is introduced through a new form of testimonial tyranny making justice a causality. Courts cannot cling to a fossil formula and insist upon corroboration even if, taken as a whole, the case spoken of by the victim of sex crime strikes the judicial mind as probable."

In another case of S. Ramakrishna Vs. The State 2008 (11) JT 635, the Apex Court while delivering this judgment also observed:

"10. A prosecutrix of a sex offence cannot be put on a par with an accomplice. She is in fact a victim of the crime. The Indian Evidence Act, 1872 (In short "the Evidence Act") nowhere says that her evidence cannot be accepted unless it is corroborated in material particulars. She is undoubtedly a competent witness under section 118 and her evidence must receive the same weight as is attached to an injured in cases of physical violence "

The contentions of ld. Counsel for accused that having not found any injury on the private part of the prosecutrix ex­facie indicates that no rape could have been committed. Ld. APP opposing the aforesaid contentions of the ld. Counsel, contended that in case 'B.C. Deva Vs. State of Karnataka 2007 VII AD (S.C.) 143= 2007 20 12 SCC 122, it has been held that merely because no injury was found on the private parts of the prosecutrix would not negate her testimony about the rape committed on her.

"18. The plea that no marks of injuries were found either on the person of the accused or the person of the prosecutrix, does not lead to any inference that the accused has not committed forcible sexual intercourse on the prosecutrix. Though the report of the gynaecologist pertaining to the medical examination of the prosecutrix does not disclose any evidence of sexual intercourse, yet even in the absence of any corroboration of medical evidence, the oral testimony of the prosecutrix, which is found to be cogent, reliable, convincing and trustworthy has to be accepted."

13.Definition of rape has been given under section 375 IPC. For the sake of clarity section 375 IPC is being re­produced verbatim which is as under:­ "375. Rape - A man is said to commit 'rape' who, except in the case hereinafter excepted, has sexual intercourse with a woman under circumstances falling under any of the six following descriptions:­ First.­ Against her will.

Secondly.­ Without her consent.

Thirdly.­ With her consent, when her consent has been obtained by putting her or any person in whom she is interested in fear of death or of hurt.

Fourthly.­ With her consent, when the man knows that he is not her husband, and that her consent is given because she believes that he is another man to whom she is or believes herself to be lawfully married.

Fifthly.­ With her consent, when, at the time of giving such consent, by reason of unsoundness of mind or intoxication or the administration by him personally or through another of any stupefying or unwholesome substance, she is unable to understand the nature and consequences of that to which she gives consent.

Sixthly.­ With or without her consent, when she is under sixteen years of age.

Explanation.­ Penetration is sufficient to constitute the sexual intercourse necessary to the offence of rape.

Explanation.­ Sexual intercourse by a man with his own wife, the wife 21 not being under fifteen years of age, is not rape."

16.However, there is blurred distinction between outraging the modesty of a woman and committal of rape. In this regard the following important observations have also been made in several cases which are as under:­ In 'Basudev Nain Vs State 1991 Cr. LJ 1594 (Ori)' it has been observed that :

"When the accused dragged a lady to some distance, stripped her of her clothing, and made her stark naked and did some immoral act not amounting to rape or attempt to rape, he is guilty under section 354 IPC".

Again in 'Kuthu Vs State of Madhya Pradesh 1998 Cr.LJ 960 (MP)' the following observation has been made ;

26
"When the accused took the prosecutrix to a lonely place by deception, then suddenly pushing bunch of leaves into her mouth and untied her undergarments, the offence of outraging modesty is proved."

In another case 'Shivraj Chandrappa Vs State of Maharashtra 1998 Cr. LJ 3168 (Bom)' it was observed that:­ "The accused asked the victim girl to go inside the room to bring the tobacco packet, followed her into the room, locked the door from inside, wrapped cloth around her mouth so that she could not should and fell her on the wooden trunk in an attempt to rape her. She anyhow removed the cloth wrapped round her mouth and shouted, released herself and ran way. The accused is guilty of outraging modesty and wrongful confinement of the victim girl."

17.The relevant section 354 IPC is being re­produced verbatim which is as under:­ Section 354 IPC "Assault or criminal force to woman with intent to outrage her modesty ­ Whoever assaults or uses criminal force to any woman, intending to outrage or knowing it to be likely that he will thereby outrage her modesty, shall be punished with imprisonment of either description for a term which may extend to two years, or with fine or with both."

18.In light of the above discussed facts and circumstances of the case I am of the view that in the catena of judgments delivered by the Apex Court it has been number of times reiterated that conviction can be safely awarded to the accused on the sole testimony of the prosecutrix but the rule of prudence required that the testimony of prosecutrix is to be examined/ scanned with great caution and circumspection . In the case in hand, prosecutrix i.e PW9 Pooja @ Monika is the sole witness who can only reveal the truth with regard to the allegation of the rape as in such cases it is difficult to prove the charge of rape. In the present 27 case Prosecutrix was a major girl being 19 years old at the time of incident. She is of sound mind. It is apparent from her testimony that she was the consented party for having made sexual intercourse with the accused precisely for the reasons that in her testimony it has categorically come on record that she was in love with the accused Surender Rai. Further, she has stated that she used to keep fast of Karva Chauth. The two photographs on record were shown to the witness and the witness identified the photographs which were taken on Karva Chauth. The accompanying boy in the photograph is accused Surender Rai. The photographs are Ex Pw9/A and Pw9/B. Further, in her testimony it has come on record that on 22 October 2005 she came nd to know that accused Surender Rai had run away with some other girl and she had lodged the present complaint on 01/11/06. The complaint is Ex Pw9/C signed by her at point A. All the members of her family came to know about the fact of physical relationship of her with the accused Surender Rai. The physical relationship was established by the accused outside the place but she does not know the name of that place. As and when the accused made a physical relationship with her no one from his family was present there however once upon a time they went to the house of sister of the accused where accused physically abused her .

In her testimony, no specific date, time and place has been brought on record. Other witnesses are formal in nature. Besides, PW2 HC Amit 28 Kumar has stated that a DD was registered at PP Raghubir Nagar regarding missing of a woman Pooja Aggarwal along with two children.

He further testified that on 02.11.06 Surender and Pooja Agarwal came to PP and Pooja stated that she had gone with accused on her own.

Moreover, PW11 Dr. Namita deposed that on local examination, her hymen was found intact and no marks of injury were found. Nowhere the matters appears to have been reported even intermittently which indicates that no sexual intercourse between the parties took place against the wishes of prosecutrix.

19.But simultaneously it can be inferred beyond reasonable doubt that at various occasions accused caused intrusion with intend to outrage the modesty of the prosecutrix. In this regard the deposition of PW9 Smt. Monika categorically reveals that accused had played a fraud with her saying that he would marry her. The accused had made forcible physical relations with her several times and she had also gone out of station together. Further, on careful perusal of her testimony it has also come on record that she admitted that when she started crying, Surender Rai asked his Jeeja to open the door. Thereafter, sister and brother­in­law of Surender Rai opened the door. They also threatened her not to narrate the incident to anybody. Prosecutrix also admitted 29 the fact that accused Surender Rai has falsely assured to marry her and had sexual intercourse with her and destroyed her life. She has also corrected her testimony that accused Yogita @ Pinky and Manoj who are the sister and Jeeja of accused Surender Rai had locked the door from outside and helped Surender Rai when he had forcible sexual intercourse with her. She correctly identified all the accused persons.

From this part of evidence it can afford the conclusion to draw the inference that accused persons caused intrusion in the life of the prosecutrix and such act of accused persons causing threat not to disclose regarding incident to anybody certainly goes to indicate that accused persons caused unchastity to the prosecutrix by threatening her, which is an offence punishable u/s 506 ­II read with 354 IPC.

20.In light of these facts and circumstances of the case and absence of corroboration from other material independent witnesses the deposition of prosecutrix to the extent of causing threat and intrusion into the life of the prosecutrix, is acceptable to the court as the corroboration is not a rule of law but the rule of prudence which culminated through the common law, as supported by judgment '2004 (1) SCC ­421 - State of Punjab Vs Ramdev Singh' So to my view under the present circumstances of the case the conviction for rape of accused in absence of independent corroboration will lead to miscarriage of justice. However, no woman in the Indian ethos and pathos and cultural traditions will tell a lie regarding her modesty and chastity in the Society, 30 so the deposition of prosecutrix cannot be denied in toto but an inference can be drawn that if no rape has been proved by some other external circumstances yet it can safely be inferred that accused impacted the unchastity of the prosecutrix which is an offence punishable u/s 506 Part II, IPC. It is well settled proposition of law that accused can be convicted for the lessor punishment. Accordingly, I convict the accused Surender Rai for the offences u/s 506 - Part II read with 354 IPC and accused persons Yogita and Manoj Kumar for the offences punishable u/s 109 r/w 509 IPC. However, accused Surender Rai is acquitted for the offences punishable u/s 376 / 366 IPC and accused Yogita and Manoj Kumar are also acquitted against the offences u/s 376/ 506 IPC precisely for the reasons discussed in the preceding paras.

Accordingly, I convict the accused Surender Rai for the offences u/s 506 - Part II read with 354 IPC and acquit him for the offences punishable u/s 376 / 366 IPC precisely for the reasons as discussed in the preceding paras; and accused persons namely Yogita and Manoj Kumar are also convicted for the offences punishable u/s 109 r/w 509 IPC and acquit them for the offence u/s 376/ 506 IPC.
